data.author: IKFA
data.content: Pokerchips, sorry I don't understand where that argument goes? Surely any gain they have from the shares they are holding, is cancelled out 1:1  with any loss on the shares which they have borrowed? It is like a zero sum game with a rent attached. For ease of numbers lets say they bought 24 million shares when the price was 26p ( so they hold the same number of shares which they have borrowed), they are enjoying the price rise up to 68p, but all of the shares which they have to buy back to cover the short has lost them exactly the same on the way up, then they have to cover the rent / interest on the borrowing ??? I understand that this would have locked in their profit at 26p but why keep the short open when you now have the ability to close it with shares which you have bought?  This is now "dead holdings" for them, which surely a hedge fund want their investment working,  not invested into a vehicle which cannot make any profit as it remains the same whichever way the stock moves ?? Also are there not rules in place to stop this practice, they have to declare "net position" to the FSA? If they have been "trading" on the way up and taking profits I could see the argument but just buying and holding makes no sense at all to me. Am I missing something?

data.author: Pokerchips
data.content: " why would they still be paying rent on 24 million shares? " well...my thoery would run along the lines  that maybe it is because they are in fact holding some shares and from them profiting from the share price gain and as such covering the "rent" cost of borrowing shares.. 2.91% short is what they have borrowed ... doesnt mean they are not actually holding any and it doesnt in itself mean they have actually sold everything they have borrowed.. I borrow shares from an owner will to offering them for borrowing... , I pay the fee..what I do with them is up to me from that point on.. Should anything turn in the hydrogen market in terms of take up and demand then the likes of Helikon will be ready to sell the shares they hold..... in the meantime those shares they hold are gaining in value and offset the ones they have sold...

data.author: IKFA
data.content: Pokerchips, sorry I don't understand where that argument goes? Surely any gain they have from the shares they are holding, is cancelled out 1:1  with any loss on the shares which they have borrowed? It is like a zero sum game with a rent attached. For ease of numbers lets say they bought 24 million shares when the price was 26p ( so they hold the same number of shares which they have borrowed), they are enjoying the price rise up to 68p, but all of the shares which they have to buy back to cover the short has lost them exactly the same on the way up, then they have to cover the rent / interest on the borrowing ??? I understand that this would have locked in their profit at 26p but why keep the short open when you now have the ability to close it with shares which you have bought?  This is now "dead holdings" for them, which surely a hedge fund want their investment working,  not invested into a vehicle which cannot make any profit as it remains the same whichever way the stock moves ?? Also are there not rules in place to stop this practice, they have to declare "net position" to the FSA? If they have been "trading" on the way up and taking profits I could see the argument but just buying and holding makes no sense at all to me. Am I missing something?

data.author: Pokerchips
data.content: " why would they still be paying rent on 24 million shares? " well...my thoery would run along the lines  that maybe it is because they are in fact holding some shares and from them profiting from the share price gain and as such covering the "rent" cost of borrowing shares.. 2.91% short is what they have borrowed ... doesnt mean they are not actually holding any and it doesnt in itself mean they have actually sold everything they have borrowed.. I borrow shares from an owner will to offering them for borrowing... , I pay the fee..what I do with them is up to me from that point on.. Should anything turn in the hydrogen market in terms of take up and demand then the likes of Helikon will be ready to sell the shares they hold..... in the meantime those shares they hold are gaining in value and offset the ones they have sold...

data.title: Half-year Financial Report
data.full_content:
Today 07:00
RNS Number : 7806Q
ITM Power PLC
29 January 2026
29 January 2026
ITM Power plc
Interim Results for the Six Months to 31 October 2025
We are pleased to present the interim results for H1, which show continued strong year-on-year progress, with revenue further increasing, EBITDA losses reducing, and a continuing strong cash position.
Interim results summary
·
Revenue of £18.0m (H1 2025: £15.5m)
·
Adjusted EBITDA loss of £11.9m (H1 2025: £16.8m)*
·
Cash on 31 October 2025 of £197.8m (31 October 2024: £203.1m)
·
Contract backlog to date of £152m, up from £43.7m two years ago, and now consisting of 71% profitable contracts as we work through our legacy contracts, up from 60% in April 2025
·
H1 highlights:
o
NEPTUNE V contract with Westnetz GmbH
o
Selected by Uniper for 120 MW HAR2 project and FEED contract signed
o
NEPTUNE II contract with a leading Spanish cement producer
o
Selected for a large-scale 300+ MW confidential project in the Asia-Pacific region
o
20 MW POSEIDON contract with MorGen Energy for their HAR1 West Wales project, which remains subject to Final Investment Decision (FID)
o
150 MW NEPTUNE V capacity reservation by RWE, with call-offs foreseen by 2027
o
FEED contract for multi-unit NEPTUNE V HAR2 project
o
Launch of Hydropulse, our new business, which will build, own and operate (BOO) decentralised green hydrogen production plants using ITM's technology, with a focus on serving industrial customers under long-term offtake agreements
·
Post period end:
o
Launch of ALPHA 50, our highly competitive new 50 MW full-scope green hydrogen plant
o
Selected for two grid balancing projects in Germany totalling 710 MW, with FIDs expected in 2026 and 2028
o
Two engineering contracts with customers in Australia and Canada
o
12.5 MW NEPTUNE V contract under HAR1 with Octopus Energy Generation
·
Reiteration of full-year guidance:
o
Revenue between £35m and £40m
o
Adjusted EBITDA loss between £27m and £29m
o
Cash £170m-£175m
*Adjusted EBITDA is a non-statutory measure. The calculation methodology is set out in
Note 3.
Dennis Schulz, CEO of ITM, said:
"We have yet again delivered our strongest six-month revenue performance to date while maintaining strict cash and operational discipline.
In the first half of the financial year, commercial activity has progressed well with the award of multiple equipment supply contracts, several engineering contracts, a significant capacity reservation from RWE, an important repeat customer, and beyond that our selection as electrolyser provider for several other upcoming projects. This progress underpins customer confidence and market traction in an environment which had to fight with known headwinds.
The Hydropulse business was well received at its launch and has since progressed several project discussions, supporting ITM's move towards recurring profitable revenue. Furthermore, Hydropulse is lining itself up to play a role in various government-backed funding programmes including HAR3 in the UK and various schemes in Germany.
Q4 saw the launch of our new product, ALPHA 50, the world's most competitive full-scope and highly efficient green hydrogen plant solution, which has generated strong interest among large-scale industrial customers.
While FID timing, of course, remains customer-led, we are closely engaged with our customers across many projects, and we expect FID momentum to continue accelerating through 2026 and beyond.
CHRONOS, our next-generation stack platform, has continued to progress through development and validation to plan. We are confident that, once launched, CHRONOS will be a true gamechanger for the electrolyser industry.
Project progress has been solid. To pick a few: The world's most advanced and largest PEM electrolyser plant, Lingen 1, for RWE has seen all 100 MW of TRIDENT stacks and skids installed and pressure-tested on time. For the second 100 MW, Lingen 2, all TRIDENT skids and already 40% of the stacks have been installed. The Leuna project with Linde is also nearing completion.
There is no doubt that green hydrogen will play an essential role in the decarbonisation of global industries and energy systems. Despite wider macroeconomic and geopolitical headwinds, clean hydrogen continues to progress at pace, with committed investments having risen elevenfold from $10bn to $110bn between 2020 and 2025
[1]
. Growth remains strongly supported by policy, increasing industrial demand, and ongoing sector consolidation - strengthening the foundations for a more resilient and commercially viable market."
Dennis Schulz, Amy Grey, and Simon Bourne will present to analysts and investors at 9:00 a.m. GMT.
The presentation will be via the Investor Meet Company platform. Questions can be submitted pre-event via the Investor Meet Company dashboard anytime and during the presentation. Analysts and investors can sign up to Investor Meet Company for free via:
https://www.investormeetcompany.com/itm-power-plc/register-investor
. Those who follow the Compa

Key Connections and Personnel Naveen Arora (US Expansion): Qube hired Naveen Arora, the former co-head of US power trading at Goldman Sachs, to lead the buildout of its first US office in Houston in 2025. Tom Gorman (COO role): Tom Gorman, previously an executive director and head of hedge fund consulting at Goldman Sachs, joined Qube as a COO in their Hong Kong office. Talent Flow: Qube has actively recruited from top-tier firms, including Goldman Sachs, as it expanded to over 1,400 employees and increased its assets under management. Systematic/Quant Focus: Both firms are deeply involved in quantitative strategies. Qube is noted as a "quant giant" that has grown in power, similar to other major players where Goldman often acts as a prime broker or competitor. Industry Trends: Goldman Sachs research highlighted that Qube is among the prominent multi-manager ("pod shop") funds experiencing record growth, and Goldman's analysis of the industry often features the hiring trends and structural growth of firms like Qube. Qube was originally spun out of Credit Suisse in 2018, but has since emerged as a major independent player by hiring extensively from investment banks like Goldman Sachs.

data.author: Dmac1966
data.content: As of 2026, RES has one of the largest onshore wind pipelines in the UK, with a heavy concentration in Scotland to support the Scottish Government’s target of 20GW by 2030. Their strategy is increasingly to co-locate or pipe this energy directly to industrial green hydrogen hubs through the HYRO joint venture. 1. Onshore Wind Farms in Planning (Scotland focus) RES is currently moving several large-scale projects through the planning system. Because of the size of these turbines, most are now handled directly by the Scottish Government's Energy Consents Unit (ECU) rather than local councils. 2. Where Green Hydrogen Facilities May Be Sited Through the HYRO partnership with Octopus, RES is targeting industrial clusters where they can replace gas usage directly. While their first major wins were in England and Wales, their Scottish strategy focuses on three key areas: • The Grangemouth Cluster: As Scotland’s largest industrial area, this is a primary target. RES/HYRO are looking at sites that can feed the refinery and petrochemical plants, competing with RWE’s nearby hydrogen proposals. • The Whiskey Industry (Speyside/Highlands): RES has a massive presence in Moray and the Highlands (e.g., Hill of Towie, Aberarder). They are exploring "decentralized" hydrogen facilities near these wind farms to supply green heat to nearby distilleries that are off the main gas grid. • Ayrshire Industrial Hub: Building on their wind assets in East Ayrshire (like Sclenteuch), they are eyeing industrial sites in this region to create a local hydrogen economy for heavy transport and manufacturing. 3. Investment Indicators In 2026, the "look" of their investment will shift from pure electricity generation to "integrated energy hubs." • The £3 Billion Fund: You will likely see HYRO announce "Behind the Meter" projects, where a wind farm connects directly to an electrolyser on an industrial site, bypassing some grid charges to make the hydrogen cheaper. • Allocation Round 7 (AR7): Keep an eye on the UK Government’s AR7 results later this year. RES/HYRO typically use these rounds to secure the guaranteed price (CfD) needed to finalize their £3bn investment decisions.

data.author: IKFA
data.content: Pokerchips, sorry I don't understand where that argument goes? Surely any gain they have from the shares they are holding, is cancelled out 1:1  with any loss on the shares which they have borrowed? It is like a zero sum game with a rent attached. For ease of numbers lets say they bought 24 million shares when the price was 26p ( so they hold the same number of shares which they have borrowed), they are enjoying the price rise up to 68p, but all of the shares which they have to buy back to cover the short has lost them exactly the same on the way up, then they have to cover the rent / interest on the borrowing ??? I understand that this would have locked in their profit at 26p but why keep the short open when you now have the ability to close it with shares which you have bought?  This is now "dead holdings" for them, which surely a hedge fund want their investment working,  not invested into a vehicle which cannot make any profit as it remains the same whichever way the stock moves ?? Also are there not rules in place to stop this practice, they have to declare "net position" to the FSA? If they have been "trading" on the way up and taking profits I could see the argument but just buying and holding makes no sense at all to me. Am I missing something?

data.author: Pokerchips
data.content: " why would they still be paying rent on 24 million shares? " well...my thoery would run along the lines  that maybe it is because they are in fact holding some shares and from them profiting from the share price gain and as such covering the "rent" cost of borrowing shares.. 2.91% short is what they have borrowed ... doesnt mean they are not actually holding any and it doesnt in itself mean they have actually sold everything they have borrowed.. I borrow shares from an owner will to offering them for borrowing... , I pay the fee..what I do with them is up to me from that point on.. Should anything turn in the hydrogen market in terms of take up and demand then the likes of Helikon will be ready to sell the shares they hold..... in the meantime those shares they hold are gaining in value and offset the ones they have sold...

data.author: Jacobjohn7
data.content: Advertise Sign In Register h2 view logo eu-approves-e3bn-german-clean-tech-manufacturing-scheme© Shutterstock EU approves €3bn German clean tech manufacturing scheme By Connor Jack on Feb 05, 2026 Translate The European Commission has greenlit €3bn ($3.5bn) in funding for Germany to incentivise clean technology manufacturing, including hydrogen solutions. The funding was approved under the June 2025 Clean Industrial Deal State Aid Framework (CISAF), which allows for continued support until the end of 2030. Eligible investments under CISAF include electrolysers, fuel cells, storage technologies, compressors, ammonia crackers, pipelines, and renewable energy infrastructure across wind, solar, and hydro. The commission said the scheme can offer support for decarbonising industrial processes “through electrification, energy efficiency and the switch to the use of renewable and electricity-based hydrogen”. The production and recycling of related critical raw materials will also be covered. Teresa Ribera, Executive Vice-President for Clean, Just and Competitive Transition, stressed the importance of the funding for reaching Clean Industrial Deal goals, saying it would also keep “potential competition distortions” to a minimum. This comes as Germany’s backing of hydrogen continues to outpace that of other EU states. Berlin and Brussels recently agreed on prospective plans to transition 12GW worth of power plants in the country to hydrogen by 2045, as well as a deal that will see Germany offer up to €200m ($232m) to Canada for importing green hydrogen. Germany also made a recent push in the mobility sector, investing €220m ($260m) into establishing a trial network of hydrogen refuelling stations, a move likely directed at EU renewable fuel of non-biological origin (RFNBO) targets.

data.author: bilboburgler
data.content: Cummins to stop new electrolyser activity after $458m hydrogen-related charges Cummins will stop pursuing new commercial activity in electrolysers after a sharp deterioration in market conditions for the hydrogen production technology. The US engine manufacturer confirmed the move in its full-year 2025 results, reporting $458m in impairment and restructuring charges linked to its electrolyser business within the Accelera by Cummins unit. Cummins Inc. said conditions in electrolysers and broader hydrogen markets deteriorated rapidly during the second half of the year, driven by weak customer demand and uncertainty around government incentives.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: I was wondering what Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) review would bring. See below from AI. The European Commission is expected to review Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) production rules by mid-2026, driven by industry calls to ease strict, costly, and complex compliance requirements. Current rules, including strict temporal and geographical correlation, are viewed as barriers to project development, with a 2026 revision likely to focus on relaxing these criteria to unlock investments and accelerate the green hydrogen market. The 2026 review is seen as a crucial turning point to transition from strict regulatory hurdles to more pragmatic, investment-friendly policies for the European hydrogen sector. Key aspects of the upcoming 2026 RFNBO review include: Potential Rule Changes: The EC is expected to review the "additionality" rule and temporal correlation requirements, which add an estimated \(\$1-2\)/kg to green hydrogen production costs. Targeted Revisions: Proposals include relaxing strict, hourly correlation to monthly, and allowing grid electricity for electrolysis when prices are low. Shift in Strategy: Due to high costs, a shift toward non-RFNBO (low-carbon/blue) hydrogen is expected in 2026, with the EC allowing this in hydrogen bank auctions. Industry Pressure: Member states and industry players have lobbied for these changes to prevent stalling projects and to ensure that 2030 targets under RED III are achievable. Revised Targets: Some forecasts suggest that the 42% industrial RFNBO target for 2030 might be abandoned or significantly revised in 2026, with Germany's subsidy-based approach becoming a template.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: From the manifesto: Europe cannot afford another missed opportunity. The choices made now will decide whether Europe leads the technologies that define the clean industrial era or becomes dependent on importing them from elsewhere. European electrolyser manufacturers have already shown what is possible. We have honoured our commitments, scaled annual production capacity and proven our ability to deliver world-class technology at industrial scale. Now, EU policymakers must match that ambition with policies that accelerate market demand, simplify regulation, and provide long-term investment certainty. Taken together, the measures described in this Manifesto would unlock immediate demand creating a functioning market for renewable and low-carbon electrolytic hydrogen. The market forces based on growing demand and competitive supply will lead to minimized costs, funding needs and risks for investors. Binding and monetisable RFNBO compliance, combined with an EU-wide book and claim “virtual pipeline” and revised rules in the RFNBO Delegated Act would ease RED III implementation across Member States, accelerate industrial and transport projects, and deliver earlier emissions cuts while laying the groundwork for the hydrogen backbone. By anchoring electrolyser manufacturing and critical component supply chains in Europe, these measures bolster resilience, reduce reliance on third country imports, and secure local high-skilled clean energy jobs. If we succeed, the benefit will be a competitive, sovereign, and resilient Europe that controls the technologies underpinning its clean-energy future, builds its own supply chains, and exports them to the world. It will mean millions of skilled jobs, and a new generation of European workers building the future rather than watching it arrive from abroad. Electrolysers can and must be the next success story for Europe: a technology driving Europe’s resilience, competitiveness, and ambition. A technology Europe builds.
data.thread_title: RE: Dennis on LinkedIn, his message from European Parliament

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: Today in the European Parliament, discussing Europe's energy future with fellow CEOs, commission and Parliament members. Europe has had a wake-up call. Energy is also about security and resilience, not just price and emissions. Europe must build and protect its own industry and supply chains for critical clean-energy equipment. Today we lead the world in electrolysers - a technology essential for decarbonisation and a strategic infrastructure supporting grid stability and energy storage. This is why global competition is intense and why Europe’s position is being challenged. The prize is an industry worth hundreds of billions, with strong export potential. German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt once said, “People with visions should go see a doctor.” He may have been right - but the electrolyser industry can deliver tens of thousands of real jobs and long-term economic growth. Europe is built on common values and fair trade. From the Nordics to the EU and the UK, we are stronger together. Trade within Europe should be open and without barriers. New legislation, including the EU Industrial Accelerator Act, must reflect this reality and support European industry, while protecting supply chains from adverse outside interference. Europe has the technology and the manufacturing base. We now also have industrial-scale reference plants. The foundations are in place. It’s time to spark industrial demand with clear policy signals and planning certainty.

data.author: breakofdawn
data.content: Verbatim 'Amy Adams, CFO, ITM Power plc: Yes, of course, but before I do that, let me just take a little step through the changes that have happened in revenue recognition. So I’m really pleased that we’ve managed to review the recognition methods. As our product portfolio grows and develops, it’s really important to take that step, step back and make sure what we’re doing is appropriate, and it’s allowed us to implement different ways of recognizing revenue to the one that we’ve historically used. So the one that we’ve historically used is completed contracts, so that’s where we recognize revenue at specific points in a contract when performance obligations are met. They could be. That could be delivery or commissioning, but generally towards the end of a contract’s life. We will still use that method for TRIDENTs, and we’ll still use that method for our standard NEPTUNE products. The difference is that NEPTUNEs that contain a customer modification, POSEIDONs or ALPHAs, will be recognized over time as we produce the equipment, and that’s really important, as we’ll be able to see the revenue track through the profit and loss as we are actually manufacturing, and leads to a lot more predictable revenue going forward. If I could give you a real-life example, if you take the Uniper 120-MW Humber project in the U.K., so that’s currently at the FEED process. So under the old recognition methods, the completed contracts method, we would recognize a small amount of revenue as we go through that FEED study, and then effectively you would see nothing else for two to three financial periods until we get towards the end of that contract and revenue would be recognized in one lump sum. If we transfer that to the new version of percentage completion, using ALPHA or POSEIDON, we’d get exactly the same revenue for the FEED study, which would be recognized at the same point in time. But the difference being that at the point that we sign the contract up until delivery, we’d be able to progressively recognize revenue. In that first financial year, you would see revenue happening for that project, and in the second, and then at delivery, until you get to the same point in time. It will allow us to be able to see progress through the factory in the P&L. Dennis Schulz, CEO, ITM Power plc: I think that’s a massive change, if I may add. In the past, when we signed a large contract, 100 MW, more than 100 MW, for example, you would not see relevant revenue from that contract for minimum 2-3 years, right? Then everything would come at once. Under the new PoC, percentage of completion, method, from contract signature, you will see revenue coming in. That is important because it changes the financial profile of the company quite significantly. What it means is, if we sign a new large contract, during a year, now, for the first time, you will see an immediate impact on guidance for the year, and you will see an immediate impact on the financial numbers of th

data.author: Dmac1966
data.content: As of 2026, RES has one of the largest onshore wind pipelines in the UK, with a heavy concentration in Scotland to support the Scottish Government’s target of 20GW by 2030. Their strategy is increasingly to co-locate or pipe this energy directly to industrial green hydrogen hubs through the HYRO joint venture. 1. Onshore Wind Farms in Planning (Scotland focus) RES is currently moving several large-scale projects through the planning system. Because of the size of these turbines, most are now handled directly by the Scottish Government's Energy Consents Unit (ECU) rather than local councils. 2. Where Green Hydrogen Facilities May Be Sited Through the HYRO partnership with Octopus, RES is targeting industrial clusters where they can replace gas usage directly. While their first major wins were in England and Wales, their Scottish strategy focuses on three key areas: • The Grangemouth Cluster: As Scotland’s largest industrial area, this is a primary target. RES/HYRO are looking at sites that can feed the refinery and petrochemical plants, competing with RWE’s nearby hydrogen proposals. • The Whiskey Industry (Speyside/Highlands): RES has a massive presence in Moray and the Highlands (e.g., Hill of Towie, Aberarder). They are exploring "decentralized" hydrogen facilities near these wind farms to supply green heat to nearby distilleries that are off the main gas grid. • Ayrshire Industrial Hub: Building on their wind assets in East Ayrshire (like Sclenteuch), they are eyeing industrial sites in this region to create a local hydrogen economy for heavy transport and manufacturing. 3. Investment Indicators In 2026, the "look" of their investment will shift from pure electricity generation to "integrated energy hubs." • The £3 Billion Fund: You will likely see HYRO announce "Behind the Meter" projects, where a wind farm connects directly to an electrolyser on an industrial site, bypassing some grid charges to make the hydrogen cheaper. • Allocation Round 7 (AR7): Keep an eye on the UK Government’s AR7 results later this year. RES/HYRO typically use these rounds to secure the guaranteed price (CfD) needed to finalize their £3bn investment decisions.

data.author: IKFA
data.content: Pokerchips, sorry I don't understand where that argument goes? Surely any gain they have from the shares they are holding, is cancelled out 1:1  with any loss on the shares which they have borrowed? It is like a zero sum game with a rent attached. For ease of numbers lets say they bought 24 million shares when the price was 26p ( so they hold the same number of shares which they have borrowed), they are enjoying the price rise up to 68p, but all of the shares which they have to buy back to cover the short has lost them exactly the same on the way up, then they have to cover the rent / interest on the borrowing ??? I understand that this would have locked in their profit at 26p but why keep the short open when you now have the ability to close it with shares which you have bought?  This is now "dead holdings" for them, which surely a hedge fund want their investment working,  not invested into a vehicle which cannot make any profit as it remains the same whichever way the stock moves ?? Also are there not rules in place to stop this practice, they have to declare "net position" to the FSA? If they have been "trading" on the way up and taking profits I could see the argument but just buying and holding makes no sense at all to me. Am I missing something?

data.author: Pokerchips
data.content: " why would they still be paying rent on 24 million shares? " well...my thoery would run along the lines  that maybe it is because they are in fact holding some shares and from them profiting from the share price gain and as such covering the "rent" cost of borrowing shares.. 2.91% short is what they have borrowed ... doesnt mean they are not actually holding any and it doesnt in itself mean they have actually sold everything they have borrowed.. I borrow shares from an owner will to offering them for borrowing... , I pay the fee..what I do with them is up to me from that point on.. Should anything turn in the hydrogen market in terms of take up and demand then the likes of Helikon will be ready to sell the shares they hold..... in the meantime those shares they hold are gaining in value and offset the ones they have sold...

data.author: wookieemonster
data.content: Have been reflecting on the Cummins situation. And seems to me the recent developments there are of benefit to ITM. “The decision is part of a broader, global restructuring of its Accelera by Cummins unit due to weak demand and ( this is the key part ) uncertainty surrounding government incentives”. This seems to prove that with Trumps policy changes and the fact they can demand repayment of grants and funds from previous years as well as remove new ones. It’s not good for USA companies, especially ones with extra costs of overseas shipping and operations. So for a smaller company like ITM this opens up a few opportunities. Firstly, they may be able to take agreed business and secondly it puts them further up the ladder of potential suppliers for new projects and those in negations in which Cummins was part of. This seems to be a very USA oriented issue with the governments current standing a key issue. It does not seems to reflect or negatively impact UK / EU or further still ( Australia, Asia etc ) And highlights the effectiveness of choosing the  Hydropulse model. Perhaps I’m mistaken, but other key players taking a back seat can only be a positive for ITM. As long as Uk / EU demand is still there and strong. Hydropulse / Chronos hopefully with strengthen the investment case, but do hope we get some positive news soon on some of our many supposedly over due FIDs to back this theory up.

data.author: Jacobjohn7
data.content: Advertise Sign In Register h2 view logo eu-approves-e3bn-german-clean-tech-manufacturing-scheme© Shutterstock EU approves €3bn German clean tech manufacturing scheme By Connor Jack on Feb 05, 2026 Translate The European Commission has greenlit €3bn ($3.5bn) in funding for Germany to incentivise clean technology manufacturing, including hydrogen solutions. The funding was approved under the June 2025 Clean Industrial Deal State Aid Framework (CISAF), which allows for continued support until the end of 2030. Eligible investments under CISAF include electrolysers, fuel cells, storage technologies, compressors, ammonia crackers, pipelines, and renewable energy infrastructure across wind, solar, and hydro. The commission said the scheme can offer support for decarbonising industrial processes “through electrification, energy efficiency and the switch to the use of renewable and electricity-based hydrogen”. The production and recycling of related critical raw materials will also be covered. Teresa Ribera, Executive Vice-President for Clean, Just and Competitive Transition, stressed the importance of the funding for reaching Clean Industrial Deal goals, saying it would also keep “potential competition distortions” to a minimum. This comes as Germany’s backing of hydrogen continues to outpace that of other EU states. Berlin and Brussels recently agreed on prospective plans to transition 12GW worth of power plants in the country to hydrogen by 2045, as well as a deal that will see Germany offer up to €200m ($232m) to Canada for importing green hydrogen. Germany also made a recent push in the mobility sector, investing €220m ($260m) into establishing a trial network of hydrogen refuelling stations, a move likely directed at EU renewable fuel of non-biological origin (RFNBO) targets.

The approval falls under the Clean Industrial Deal State Aid Framework (CISAF), adopted in June 2025, which allows support until the end of 2030 for net-zero technologies and related critical raw materials. https://fuelcellsworks.com/2026/02/05/news/eu-approves-3bn-german-aid-that-includes-aid-for-hydrogen-manufacturing

data.author: bilboburgler
data.content: Cummins to stop new electrolyser activity after $458m hydrogen-related charges Cummins will stop pursuing new commercial activity in electrolysers after a sharp deterioration in market conditions for the hydrogen production technology. The US engine manufacturer confirmed the move in its full-year 2025 results, reporting $458m in impairment and restructuring charges linked to its electrolyser business within the Accelera by Cummins unit. Cummins Inc. said conditions in electrolysers and broader hydrogen markets deteriorated rapidly during the second half of the year, driven by weak customer demand and uncertainty around government incentives.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: I was wondering what Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) review would bring. See below from AI. The European Commission is expected to review Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) production rules by mid-2026, driven by industry calls to ease strict, costly, and complex compliance requirements. Current rules, including strict temporal and geographical correlation, are viewed as barriers to project development, with a 2026 revision likely to focus on relaxing these criteria to unlock investments and accelerate the green hydrogen market. The 2026 review is seen as a crucial turning point to transition from strict regulatory hurdles to more pragmatic, investment-friendly policies for the European hydrogen sector. Key aspects of the upcoming 2026 RFNBO review include: Potential Rule Changes: The EC is expected to review the "additionality" rule and temporal correlation requirements, which add an estimated \(\$1-2\)/kg to green hydrogen production costs. Targeted Revisions: Proposals include relaxing strict, hourly correlation to monthly, and allowing grid electricity for electrolysis when prices are low. Shift in Strategy: Due to high costs, a shift toward non-RFNBO (low-carbon/blue) hydrogen is expected in 2026, with the EC allowing this in hydrogen bank auctions. Industry Pressure: Member states and industry players have lobbied for these changes to prevent stalling projects and to ensure that 2030 targets under RED III are achievable. Revised Targets: Some forecasts suggest that the 42% industrial RFNBO target for 2030 might be abandoned or significantly revised in 2026, with Germany's subsidy-based approach becoming a template.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: From the manifesto: Europe cannot afford another missed opportunity. The choices made now will decide whether Europe leads the technologies that define the clean industrial era or becomes dependent on importing them from elsewhere. European electrolyser manufacturers have already shown what is possible. We have honoured our commitments, scaled annual production capacity and proven our ability to deliver world-class technology at industrial scale. Now, EU policymakers must match that ambition with policies that accelerate market demand, simplify regulation, and provide long-term investment certainty. Taken together, the measures described in this Manifesto would unlock immediate demand creating a functioning market for renewable and low-carbon electrolytic hydrogen. The market forces based on growing demand and competitive supply will lead to minimized costs, funding needs and risks for investors. Binding and monetisable RFNBO compliance, combined with an EU-wide book and claim “virtual pipeline” and revised rules in the RFNBO Delegated Act would ease RED III implementation across Member States, accelerate industrial and transport projects, and deliver earlier emissions cuts while laying the groundwork for the hydrogen backbone. By anchoring electrolyser manufacturing and critical component supply chains in Europe, these measures bolster resilience, reduce reliance on third country imports, and secure local high-skilled clean energy jobs. If we succeed, the benefit will be a competitive, sovereign, and resilient Europe that controls the technologies underpinning its clean-energy future, builds its own supply chains, and exports them to the world. It will mean millions of skilled jobs, and a new generation of European workers building the future rather than watching it arrive from abroad. Electrolysers can and must be the next success story for Europe: a technology driving Europe’s resilience, competitiveness, and ambition. A technology Europe builds.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: Today in the European Parliament, discussing Europe's energy future with fellow CEOs, commission and Parliament members. Europe has had a wake-up call. Energy is also about security and resilience, not just price and emissions. Europe must build and protect its own industry and supply chains for critical clean-energy equipment. Today we lead the world in electrolysers - a technology essential for decarbonisation and a strategic infrastructure supporting grid stability and energy storage. This is why global competition is intense and why Europe’s position is being challenged. The prize is an industry worth hundreds of billions, with strong export potential. German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt once said, “People with visions should go see a doctor.” He may have been right - but the electrolyser industry can deliver tens of thousands of real jobs and long-term economic growth. Europe is built on common values and fair trade. From the Nordics to the EU and the UK, we are stronger together. Trade within Europe should be open and without barriers. New legislation, including the EU Industrial Accelerator Act, must reflect this reality and support European industry, while protecting supply chains from adverse outside interference. Europe has the technology and the manufacturing base. We now also have industrial-scale reference plants. The foundations are in place. It’s time to spark industrial demand with clear policy signals and planning certainty.

data.author: breakofdawn
data.content: Verbatim 'Amy Adams, CFO, ITM Power plc: Yes, of course, but before I do that, let me just take a little step through the changes that have happened in revenue recognition. So I’m really pleased that we’ve managed to review the recognition methods. As our product portfolio grows and develops, it’s really important to take that step, step back and make sure what we’re doing is appropriate, and it’s allowed us to implement different ways of recognizing revenue to the one that we’ve historically used. So the one that we’ve historically used is completed contracts, so that’s where we recognize revenue at specific points in a contract when performance obligations are met. They could be. That could be delivery or commissioning, but generally towards the end of a contract’s life. We will still use that method for TRIDENTs, and we’ll still use that method for our standard NEPTUNE products. The difference is that NEPTUNEs that contain a customer modification, POSEIDONs or ALPHAs, will be recognized over time as we produce the equipment, and that’s really important, as we’ll be able to see the revenue track through the profit and loss as we are actually manufacturing, and leads to a lot more predictable revenue going forward. If I could give you a real-life example, if you take the Uniper 120-MW Humber project in the U.K., so that’s currently at the FEED process. So under the old recognition methods, the completed contracts method, we would recognize a small amount of revenue as we go through that FEED study, and then effectively you would see nothing else for two to three financial periods until we get towards the end of that contract and revenue would be recognized in one lump sum. If we transfer that to the new version of percentage completion, using ALPHA or POSEIDON, we’d get exactly the same revenue for the FEED study, which would be recognized at the same point in time. But the difference being that at the point that we sign the contract up until delivery, we’d be able to progressively recognize revenue. In that first financial year, you would see revenue happening for that project, and in the second, and then at delivery, until you get to the same point in time. It will allow us to be able to see progress through the factory in the P&L. Dennis Schulz, CEO, ITM Power plc: I think that’s a massive change, if I may add. In the past, when we signed a large contract, 100 MW, more than 100 MW, for example, you would not see relevant revenue from that contract for minimum 2-3 years, right? Then everything would come at once. Under the new PoC, percentage of completion, method, from contract signature, you will see revenue coming in. That is important because it changes the financial profile of the company quite significantly. What it means is, if we sign a new large contract, during a year, now, for the first time, you will see an immediate impact on guidance for the year, and you will see an immediate impact on the financial numbers of th

"market manipulation cases are complex and more difficult to investigate than insider dealing or other types of market abuse (see FCA: Market integrity and strategic approach (7 February 2020)). data.content: From AI Quote: Goldman Sachs has several notable connections to Qube Research & Technologies (QRT), a rapidly growing London-based quantitative hedge fund that manages over $30 billion. These links primarily involve the poaching of senior talent for expansion and the use of similar, high-tech, multi-manager structures. Key Connections and Personnel Naveen Arora (US Expansion): Qube hired Naveen Arora, the former co-head of US power trading at Goldman Sachs, to lead the buildout of its first US office in Houston in 2025. This move is central to Qube's expansion into physical commodity trading in the US. Tom Gorman (COO role): Tom Gorman, previously an executive director and head of hedge fund consulting at Goldman Sachs, joined Qube as a COO in their Hong Kong office. Talent Flow: Qube has actively recruited from top-tier firms, including Goldman Sachs, as it expanded to over 1,400 employees and increased its assets under management. Systematic/Quant Focus: Both firms are deeply involved in quantitative strategies. Qube is noted as a "quant giant" that has grown in power, similar to other major players where Goldman often acts as a prime broker or competitor. Industry Trends: Goldman Sachs research highlighted that Qube is among the prominent multi-manager ("pod shop") funds experiencing record growth, and Goldman's analysis of the industry often features the hiring trends and structural growth of firms like Qube. Qube was originally spun out of Credit Suisse in 2018, but has since emerged as a major independent player by hiring extensively from investment banks like Goldman Sachs.

data.author: Dmac1966
data.content: As of 2026, RES has one of the largest onshore wind pipelines in the UK, with a heavy concentration in Scotland to support the Scottish Government’s target of 20GW by 2030. Their strategy is increasingly to co-locate or pipe this energy directly to industrial green hydrogen hubs through the HYRO joint venture. 1. Onshore Wind Farms in Planning (Scotland focus) RES is currently moving several large-scale projects through the planning system. Because of the size of these turbines, most are now handled directly by the Scottish Government's Energy Consents Unit (ECU) rather than local councils. 2. Where Green Hydrogen Facilities May Be Sited Through the HYRO partnership with Octopus, RES is targeting industrial clusters where they can replace gas usage directly. While their first major wins were in England and Wales, their Scottish strategy focuses on three key areas: • The Grangemouth Cluster: As Scotland’s largest industrial area, this is a primary target. RES/HYRO are looking at sites that can feed the refinery and petrochemical plants, competing with RWE’s nearby hydrogen proposals. • The Whiskey Industry (Speyside/Highlands): RES has a massive presence in Moray and the Highlands (e.g., Hill of Towie, Aberarder). They are exploring "decentralized" hydrogen facilities near these wind farms to supply green heat to nearby distilleries that are off the main gas grid. • Ayrshire Industrial Hub: Building on their wind assets in East Ayrshire (like Sclenteuch), they are eyeing industrial sites in this region to create a local hydrogen economy for heavy transport and manufacturing. 3. Investment Indicators In 2026, the "look" of their investment will shift from pure electricity generation to "integrated energy hubs." • The £3 Billion Fund: You will likely see HYRO announce "Behind the Meter" projects, where a wind farm connects directly to an electrolyser on an industrial site, bypassing some grid charges to make the hydrogen cheaper. • Allocation Round 7 (AR7): Keep an eye on the UK Government’s AR7 results later this year. RES/HYRO typically use these rounds to secure the guaranteed price (CfD) needed to finalize their £3bn investment decisions.

data.author: JeremyF1965
data.content: Shorts. If you are short a stock but long in the same stock you usually have to declare the net position. But if they are gambling that say 'plug' is going to go up more than ITM in the same industry, you short one and go long in the other. If the industry as a whole goes up or down it doesn't affect you - the bet is on the relative strength of the 2 companies in play. Personally I would NOT bet against ITM. .

data.author: IKFA
data.content: Pokerchips, sorry I don't understand where that argument goes? Surely any gain they have from the shares they are holding, is cancelled out 1:1  with any loss on the shares which they have borrowed? It is like a zero sum game with a rent attached. For ease of numbers lets say they bought 24 million shares when the price was 26p ( so they hold the same number of shares which they have borrowed), they are enjoying the price rise up to 68p, but all of the shares which they have to buy back to cover the short has lost them exactly the same on the way up, then they have to cover the rent / interest on the borrowing ??? I understand that this would have locked in their profit at 26p but why keep the short open when you now have the ability to close it with shares which you have bought?  This is now "dead holdings" for them, which surely a hedge fund want their investment working,  not invested into a vehicle which cannot make any profit as it remains the same whichever way the stock moves ?? Also are there not rules in place to stop this practice, they have to declare "net position" to the FSA? If they have been "trading" on the way up and taking profits I could see the argument but just buying and holding makes no sense at all to me. Am I missing something?

data.author: Pokerchips
data.content: " why would they still be paying rent on 24 million shares? " well...my thoery would run along the lines  that maybe it is because they are in fact holding some shares and from them profiting from the share price gain and as such covering the "rent" cost of borrowing shares.. 2.91% short is what they have borrowed ... doesnt mean they are not actually holding any and it doesnt in itself mean they have actually sold everything they have borrowed.. I borrow shares from an owner will to offering them for borrowing... , I pay the fee..what I do with them is up to me from that point on.. Should anything turn in the hydrogen market in terms of take up and demand then the likes of Helikon will be ready to sell the shares they hold..... in the meantime those shares they hold are gaining in value and offset the ones they have sold...

data.author: wookieemonster
data.content: Have been reflecting on the Cummins situation. And seems to me the recent developments there are of benefit to ITM. “The decision is part of a broader, global restructuring of its Accelera by Cummins unit due to weak demand and ( this is the key part ) uncertainty surrounding government incentives”. This seems to prove that with Trumps policy changes and the fact they can demand repayment of grants and funds from previous years as well as remove new ones. It’s not good for USA companies, especially ones with extra costs of overseas shipping and operations. So for a smaller company like ITM this opens up a few opportunities. Firstly, they may be able to take agreed business and secondly it puts them further up the ladder of potential suppliers for new projects and those in negations in which Cummins was part of. This seems to be a very USA oriented issue with the governments current standing a key issue. It does not seems to reflect or negatively impact UK / EU or further still ( Australia, Asia etc ) And highlights the effectiveness of choosing the  Hydropulse model. Perhaps I’m mistaken, but other key players taking a back seat can only be a positive for ITM. As long as Uk / EU demand is still there and strong. Hydropulse / Chronos hopefully with strengthen the investment case, but do hope we get some positive news soon on some of our many supposedly over due FIDs to back this theory up.

data.author: Jacobjohn7
data.content: Advertise Sign In Register h2 view logo eu-approves-e3bn-german-clean-tech-manufacturing-scheme© Shutterstock EU approves €3bn German clean tech manufacturing scheme By Connor Jack on Feb 05, 2026 Translate The European Commission has greenlit €3bn ($3.5bn) in funding for Germany to incentivise clean technology manufacturing, including hydrogen solutions. The funding was approved under the June 2025 Clean Industrial Deal State Aid Framework (CISAF), which allows for continued support until the end of 2030. Eligible investments under CISAF include electrolysers, fuel cells, storage technologies, compressors, ammonia crackers, pipelines, and renewable energy infrastructure across wind, solar, and hydro. The commission said the scheme can offer support for decarbonising industrial processes “through electrification, energy efficiency and the switch to the use of renewable and electricity-based hydrogen”. The production and recycling of related critical raw materials will also be covered. Teresa Ribera, Executive Vice-President for Clean, Just and Competitive Transition, stressed the importance of the funding for reaching Clean Industrial Deal goals, saying it would also keep “potential competition distortions” to a minimum. This comes as Germany’s backing of hydrogen continues to outpace that of other EU states. Berlin and Brussels recently agreed on prospective plans to transition 12GW worth of power plants in the country to hydrogen by 2045, as well as a deal that will see Germany offer up to €200m ($232m) to Canada for importing green hydrogen. Germany also made a recent push in the mobility sector, investing €220m ($260m) into establishing a trial network of hydrogen refuelling stations, a move likely directed at EU renewable fuel of non-biological origin (RFNBO) targets.

data.author: bilboburgler
data.content: Cummins to stop new electrolyser activity after $458m hydrogen-related charges Cummins will stop pursuing new commercial activity in electrolysers after a sharp deterioration in market conditions for the hydrogen production technology. The US engine manufacturer confirmed the move in its full-year 2025 results, reporting $458m in impairment and restructuring charges linked to its electrolyser business within the Accelera by Cummins unit. Cummins Inc. said conditions in electrolysers and broader hydrogen markets deteriorated rapidly during the second half of the year, driven by weak customer demand and uncertainty around government incentives.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: I was wondering what Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) review would bring. See below from AI. The European Commission is expected to review Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) production rules by mid-2026, driven by industry calls to ease strict, costly, and complex compliance requirements. Current rules, including strict temporal and geographical correlation, are viewed as barriers to project development, with a 2026 revision likely to focus on relaxing these criteria to unlock investments and accelerate the green hydrogen market. The 2026 review is seen as a crucial turning point to transition from strict regulatory hurdles to more pragmatic, investment-friendly policies for the European hydrogen sector. Key aspects of the upcoming 2026 RFNBO review include: Potential Rule Changes: The EC is expected to review the "additionality" rule and temporal correlation requirements, which add an estimated \(\$1-2\)/kg to green hydrogen production costs. Targeted Revisions: Proposals include relaxing strict, hourly correlation to monthly, and allowing grid electricity for electrolysis when prices are low. Shift in Strategy: Due to high costs, a shift toward non-RFNBO (low-carbon/blue) hydrogen is expected in 2026, with the EC allowing this in hydrogen bank auctions. Industry Pressure: Member states and industry players have lobbied for these changes to prevent stalling projects and to ensure that 2030 targets under RED III are achievable. Revised Targets: Some forecasts suggest that the 42% industrial RFNBO target for 2030 might be abandoned or significantly revised in 2026, with Germany's subsidy-based approach becoming a template.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: From the manifesto: Europe cannot afford another missed opportunity. The choices made now will decide whether Europe leads the technologies that define the clean industrial era or becomes dependent on importing them from elsewhere. European electrolyser manufacturers have already shown what is possible. We have honoured our commitments, scaled annual production capacity and proven our ability to deliver world-class technology at industrial scale. Now, EU policymakers must match that ambition with policies that accelerate market demand, simplify regulation, and provide long-term investment certainty. Taken together, the measures described in this Manifesto would unlock immediate demand creating a functioning market for renewable and low-carbon electrolytic hydrogen. The market forces based on growing demand and competitive supply will lead to minimized costs, funding needs and risks for investors. Binding and monetisable RFNBO compliance, combined with an EU-wide book and claim “virtual pipeline” and revised rules in the RFNBO Delegated Act would ease RED III implementation across Member States, accelerate industrial and transport projects, and deliver earlier emissions cuts while laying the groundwork for the hydrogen backbone. By anchoring electrolyser manufacturing and critical component supply chains in Europe, these measures bolster resilience, reduce reliance on third country imports, and secure local high-skilled clean energy jobs. If we succeed, the benefit will be a competitive, sovereign, and resilient Europe that controls the technologies underpinning its clean-energy future, builds its own supply chains, and exports them to the world. It will mean millions of skilled jobs, and a new generation of European workers building the future rather than watching it arrive from abroad. Electrolysers can and must be the next success story for Europe: a technology driving Europe’s resilience, competitiveness, and ambition. A technology Europe builds.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: Today in the European Parliament, discussing Europe's energy future with fellow CEOs, commission and Parliament members. Europe has had a wake-up call. Energy is also about security and resilience, not just price and emissions. Europe must build and protect its own industry and supply chains for critical clean-energy equipment. Today we lead the world in electrolysers - a technology essential for decarbonisation and a strategic infrastructure supporting grid stability and energy storage. This is why global competition is intense and why Europe’s position is being challenged. The prize is an industry worth hundreds of billions, with strong export potential. German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt once said, “People with visions should go see a doctor.” He may have been right - but the electrolyser industry can deliver tens of thousands of real jobs and long-term economic growth. Europe is built on common values and fair trade. From the Nordics to the EU and the UK, we are stronger together. Trade within Europe should be open and without barriers. New legislation, including the EU Industrial Accelerator Act, must reflect this reality and support European industry, while protecting supply chains from adverse outside interference. Europe has the technology and the manufacturing base. We now also have industrial-scale reference plants. The foundations are in place. It’s time to spark industrial demand with clear policy signals and planning certainty.

data.author: breakofdawn
data.content: Verbatim 'Amy Adams, CFO, ITM Power plc: Yes, of course, but before I do that, let me just take a little step through the changes that have happened in revenue recognition. So I’m really pleased that we’ve managed to review the recognition methods. As our product portfolio grows and develops, it’s really important to take that step, step back and make sure what we’re doing is appropriate, and it’s allowed us to implement different ways of recognizing revenue to the one that we’ve historically used. So the one that we’ve historically used is completed contracts, so that’s where we recognize revenue at specific points in a contract when performance obligations are met. They could be. That could be delivery or commissioning, but generally towards the end of a contract’s life. We will still use that method for TRIDENTs, and we’ll still use that method for our standard NEPTUNE products. The difference is that NEPTUNEs that contain a customer modification, POSEIDONs or ALPHAs, will be recognized over time as we produce the equipment, and that’s really important, as we’ll be able to see the revenue track through the profit and loss as we are actually manufacturing, and leads to a lot more predictable revenue going forward. If I could give you a real-life example, if you take the Uniper 120-MW Humber project in the U.K., so that’s currently at the FEED process. So under the old recognition methods, the completed contracts method, we would recognize a small amount of revenue as we go through that FEED study, and then effectively you would see nothing else for two to three financial periods until we get towards the end of that contract and revenue would be recognized in one lump sum. If we transfer that to the new version of percentage completion, using ALPHA or POSEIDON, we’d get exactly the same revenue for the FEED study, which would be recognized at the same point in time. But the difference being that at the point that we sign the contract up until delivery, we’d be able to progressively recognize revenue. In that first financial year, you would see revenue happening for that project, and in the second, and then at delivery, until you get to the same point in time. It will allow us to be able to see progress through the factory in the P&L. Dennis Schulz, CEO, ITM Power plc: I think that’s a massive change, if I may add. In the past, when we signed a large contract, 100 MW, more than 100 MW, for example, you would not see relevant revenue from that contract for minimum 2-3 years, right? Then everything would come at once. Under the new PoC, percentage of completion, method, from contract signature, you will see revenue coming in. That is important because it changes the financial profile of the company quite significantly. What it means is, if we sign a new large contract, during a year, now, for the first time, you will see an immediate impact on guidance for the year, and you will see an immediate impact on the financial numbers of th

data.author: Dmac1966
data.content: As of 2026, RES has one of the largest onshore wind pipelines in the UK, with a heavy concentration in Scotland to support the Scottish Government’s target of 20GW by 2030. Their strategy is increasingly to co-locate or pipe this energy directly to industrial green hydrogen hubs through the HYRO joint venture. 1. Onshore Wind Farms in Planning (Scotland focus) RES is currently moving several large-scale projects through the planning system. Because of the size of these turbines, most are now handled directly by the Scottish Government's Energy Consents Unit (ECU) rather than local councils. 2. Where Green Hydrogen Facilities May Be Sited Through the HYRO partnership with Octopus, RES is targeting industrial clusters where they can replace gas usage directly. While their first major wins were in England and Wales, their Scottish strategy focuses on three key areas: • The Grangemouth Cluster: As Scotland’s largest industrial area, this is a primary target. RES/HYRO are looking at sites that can feed the refinery and petrochemical plants, competing with RWE’s nearby hydrogen proposals. • The Whiskey Industry (Speyside/Highlands): RES has a massive presence in Moray and the Highlands (e.g., Hill of Towie, Aberarder). They are exploring "decentralized" hydrogen facilities near these wind farms to supply green heat to nearby distilleries that are off the main gas grid. • Ayrshire Industrial Hub: Building on their wind assets in East Ayrshire (like Sclenteuch), they are eyeing industrial sites in this region to create a local hydrogen economy for heavy transport and manufacturing. 3. Investment Indicators In 2026, the "look" of their investment will shift from pure electricity generation to "integrated energy hubs." • The £3 Billion Fund: You will likely see HYRO announce "Behind the Meter" projects, where a wind farm connects directly to an electrolyser on an industrial site, bypassing some grid charges to make the hydrogen cheaper. • Allocation Round 7 (AR7): Keep an eye on the UK Government’s AR7 results later this year. RES/HYRO typically use these rounds to secure the guaranteed price (CfD) needed to finalize their £3bn investment decisions.

data.author: IKFA
data.content: Pokerchips, sorry I don't understand where that argument goes? Surely any gain they have from the shares they are holding, is cancelled out 1:1  with any loss on the shares which they have borrowed? It is like a zero sum game with a rent attached. For ease of numbers lets say they bought 24 million shares when the price was 26p ( so they hold the same number of shares which they have borrowed), they are enjoying the price rise up to 68p, but all of the shares which they have to buy back to cover the short has lost them exactly the same on the way up, then they have to cover the rent / interest on the borrowing ??? I understand that this would have locked in their profit at 26p but why keep the short open when you now have the ability to close it with shares which you have bought?  This is now "dead holdings" for them, which surely a hedge fund want their investment working,  not invested into a vehicle which cannot make any profit as it remains the same whichever way the stock moves ?? Also are there not rules in place to stop this practice, they have to declare "net position" to the FSA? If they have been "trading" on the way up and taking profits I could see the argument but just buying and holding makes no sense at all to me. Am I missing something?

data.content: " why would they still be paying rent on 24 million shares? " well...my thoery would run along the lines  that maybe it is because they are in fact holding some shares and from them profiting from the share price gain and as such covering the "rent" cost of borrowing shares.. 2.91% short is what they have borrowed ... doesnt mean they are not actually holding any and it doesnt in itself mean they have actually sold everything they have borrowed.. I borrow shares from an owner will to offering them for borrowing... , I pay the fee..what I do with them is up to me from that point on.. data.author: SatellitePro
data.content: Quote - Heavily shorted shares often come under sustained pressure designed to prevent them from rising, a phenomenon sometimes referred to as a "short attack" or a "bear raid". Short sellers, having bet on a price decline, may use various strategies to ensure the stock price stays down to secure a profit. Here is a breakdown of how this process works, the techniques used, and the associated risks: How Heavily Shorted Stocks Are Attacked "Short and Distort" Campaigns: Activist short sellers may publish negative reports, blog posts, or social media commentary highlighting unfavorable information to panic other investors into selling. Sustained Selling Pressure: Short sellers may actively sell borrowed shares in a coordinated fashion to create artificial downward pressure, attempting to push the price below a company’s fundamental value. Shorting Counter trend Bounces: When a stock tries to rise, short sellers may aggressively sell into that rally to cap the price and prevent it from breaking out. High Short Interest as a Signal: When short interest exceeds 10%–20% of the float, it signals a crowded trade where a large number of market participants are actively working to keep the price down. The Role of Market Mechanics Lowered Confidence: The constant negative reinforcement and price suppression can cause long-term investors to lose confidence and sell. Margin Calls on Longs: If the price is forced down, it may trigger margin calls for long investors, forcing them to sell and creating further downward pressure. The Danger: The "Short Squeeze" While these attacks aim to stop a price rise, they also make the stock extremely volatile and vulnerable to a short squeeze. If the stock price rises despite the pressure—perhaps due to positive news or high buying volume—short sellers are forced to cover their positions by buying shares, which can cause the price to skyrocket rapidly. When Attacks Backfire: The same high short interest that allows for a "sustained attack" also acts as fuel for a violent upward surge if the bears are forced to cover. Retail/Social Media Impact: In recent years, collective buying (e.g., from platforms like Reddit) has been used to counter these attacks and trigger squeezes. In summary, heavily shorted stocks are often under intense pressure to stay down, but they are also frequently "coiled springs" that can experience violent, upward, "short-squeeze" movements if their price starts to rise.

data.author: wookieemonster
data.content: Have been reflecting on the Cummins situation. And seems to me the recent developments there are of benefit to ITM. “The decision is part of a broader, global restructuring of its Accelera by Cummins unit due to weak demand and ( this is the key part ) uncertainty surrounding government incentives”. This seems to prove that with Trumps policy changes and the fact they can demand repayment of grants and funds from previous years as well as remove new ones. It’s not good for USA companies, especially ones with extra costs of overseas shipping and operations. So for a smaller company like ITM this opens up a few opportunities. Firstly, they may be able to take agreed business and secondly it puts them further up the ladder of potential suppliers for new projects and those in negations in which Cummins was part of. This seems to be a very USA oriented issue with the governments current standing a key issue. It does not seems to reflect or negatively impact UK / EU or further still ( Australia, Asia etc ) And highlights the effectiveness of choosing the  Hydropulse model. Perhaps I’m mistaken, but other key players taking a back seat can only be a positive for ITM. As long as Uk / EU demand is still there and strong. Hydropulse / Chronos hopefully with strengthen the investment case, but do hope we get some positive news soon on some of our many supposedly over due FIDs to back this theory up.

data.author: Jacobjohn7
data.content: Advertise Sign In Register h2 view logo eu-approves-e3bn-german-clean-tech-manufacturing-scheme© Shutterstock EU approves €3bn German clean tech manufacturing scheme By Connor Jack on Feb 05, 2026 Translate The European Commission has greenlit €3bn ($3.5bn) in funding for Germany to incentivise clean technology manufacturing, including hydrogen solutions. The funding was approved under the June 2025 Clean Industrial Deal State Aid Framework (CISAF), which allows for continued support until the end of 2030. Eligible investments under CISAF include electrolysers, fuel cells, storage technologies, compressors, ammonia crackers, pipelines, and renewable energy infrastructure across wind, solar, and hydro. The commission said the scheme can offer support for decarbonising industrial processes “through electrification, energy efficiency and the switch to the use of renewable and electricity-based hydrogen”. The production and recycling of related critical raw materials will also be covered. Teresa Ribera, Executive Vice-President for Clean, Just and Competitive Transition, stressed the importance of the funding for reaching Clean Industrial Deal goals, saying it would also keep “potential competition distortions” to a minimum. This comes as Germany’s backing of hydrogen continues to outpace that of other EU states. Berlin and Brussels recently agreed on prospective plans to transition 12GW worth of power plants in the country to hydrogen by 2045, as well as a deal that will see Germany offer up to €200m ($232m) to Canada for importing green hydrogen. Germany also made a recent push in the mobility sector, investing €220m ($260m) into establishing a trial network of hydrogen refuelling stations, a move likely directed at EU renewable fuel of non-biological origin (RFNBO) targets.

The approval falls under the Clean Industrial Deal State Aid Framework (CISAF), adopted in June 2025, which allows support until the end of 2030 for net-zero technologies and related critical raw materials. https://fuelcellsworks.com/2026/02/05/news/eu-approves-3bn-german-aid-that-includes-aid-for-hydrogen-manufacturing

data.author: bilboburgler
data.content: Cummins to stop new electrolyser activity after $458m hydrogen-related charges Cummins will stop pursuing new commercial activity in electrolysers after a sharp deterioration in market conditions for the hydrogen production technology. The US engine manufacturer confirmed the move in its full-year 2025 results, reporting $458m in impairment and restructuring charges linked to its electrolyser business within the Accelera by Cummins unit. Cummins Inc. said conditions in electrolysers and broader hydrogen markets deteriorated rapidly during the second half of the year, driven by weak customer demand and uncertainty around government incentives.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: I was wondering what Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) review would bring. See below from AI. The European Commission is expected to review Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) production rules by mid-2026, driven by industry calls to ease strict, costly, and complex compliance requirements. Current rules, including strict temporal and geographical correlation, are viewed as barriers to project development, with a 2026 revision likely to focus on relaxing these criteria to unlock investments and accelerate the green hydrogen market. The 2026 review is seen as a crucial turning point to transition from strict regulatory hurdles to more pragmatic, investment-friendly policies for the European hydrogen sector. Key aspects of the upcoming 2026 RFNBO review include: Potential Rule Changes: The EC is expected to review the "additionality" rule and temporal correlation requirements, which add an estimated \(\$1-2\)/kg to green hydrogen production costs. Targeted Revisions: Proposals include relaxing strict, hourly correlation to monthly, and allowing grid electricity for electrolysis when prices are low. Shift in Strategy: Due to high costs, a shift toward non-RFNBO (low-carbon/blue) hydrogen is expected in 2026, with the EC allowing this in hydrogen bank auctions. Industry Pressure: Member states and industry players have lobbied for these changes to prevent stalling projects and to ensure that 2030 targets under RED III are achievable. Revised Targets: Some forecasts suggest that the 42% industrial RFNBO target for 2030 might be abandoned or significantly revised in 2026, with Germany's subsidy-based approach becoming a template.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: From the manifesto: Europe cannot afford another missed opportunity. The choices made now will decide whether Europe leads the technologies that define the clean industrial era or becomes dependent on importing them from elsewhere. European electrolyser manufacturers have already shown what is possible. We have honoured our commitments, scaled annual production capacity and proven our ability to deliver world-class technology at industrial scale. Now, EU policymakers must match that ambition with policies that accelerate market demand, simplify regulation, and provide long-term investment certainty. Taken together, the measures described in this Manifesto would unlock immediate demand creating a functioning market for renewable and low-carbon electrolytic hydrogen. The market forces based on growing demand and competitive supply will lead to minimized costs, funding needs and risks for investors. Binding and monetisable RFNBO compliance, combined with an EU-wide book and claim “virtual pipeline” and revised rules in the RFNBO Delegated Act would ease RED III implementation across Member States, accelerate industrial and transport projects, and deliver earlier emissions cuts while laying the groundwork for the hydrogen backbone. By anchoring electrolyser manufacturing and critical component supply chains in Europe, these measures bolster resilience, reduce reliance on third country imports, and secure local high-skilled clean energy jobs. If we succeed, the benefit will be a competitive, sovereign, and resilient Europe that controls the technologies underpinning its clean-energy future, builds its own supply chains, and exports them to the world. It will mean millions of skilled jobs, and a new generation of European workers building the future rather than watching it arrive from abroad. Electrolysers can and must be the next success story for Europe: a technology driving Europe’s resilience, competitiveness, and ambition. A technology Europe builds.

data.author: vamosbien
data.content: Today in the European Parliament, discussing Europe's energy future with fellow CEOs, commission and Parliament members. Europe has had a wake-up call. Energy is also about security and resilience, not just price and emissions. Europe must build and protect its own industry and supply chains for critical clean-energy equipment. Today we lead the world in electrolysers - a technology essential for decarbonisation and a strategic infrastructure supporting grid stability and energy storage. This is why global competition is intense and why Europe’s position is being challenged. The prize is an industry worth hundreds of billions, with strong export potential. German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt once said, “People with visions should go see a doctor.” He may have been right - but the electrolyser industry can deliver tens of thousands of real jobs and long-term economic growth. Europe is built on common values and fair trade. From the Nordics to the EU and the UK, we are stronger together. Trade within Europe should be open and without barriers. New legislation, including the EU Industrial Accelerator Act, must reflect this reality and support European industry, while protecting supply chains from adverse outside interference. Europe has the technology and the manufacturing base. We now also have industrial-scale reference plants. The foundations are in place. It’s time to spark industrial demand with clear policy signals and planning certainty.
