data.author: breakofdawn
data.content: Verbatim 'Amy Adams, CFO, ITM Power plc: Yes, of course, but before I do that, let me just take a little step through the changes that have happened in revenue recognition. So I’m really pleased that we’ve managed to review the recognition methods. As our product portfolio grows and develops, it’s really important to take that step, step back and make sure what we’re doing is appropriate, and it’s allowed us to implement different ways of recognizing revenue to the one that we’ve historically used. So the one that we’ve historically used is completed contracts, so that’s where we recognize revenue at specific points in a contract when performance obligations are met. They could be. That could be delivery or commissioning, but generally towards the end of a contract’s life. We will still use that method for TRIDENTs, and we’ll still use that method for our standard NEPTUNE products. The difference is that NEPTUNEs that contain a customer modification, POSEIDONs or ALPHAs, will be recognized over time as we produce the equipment, and that’s really important, as we’ll be able to see the revenue track through the profit and loss as we are actually manufacturing, and leads to a lot more predictable revenue going forward. If I could give you a real-life example, if you take the Uniper 120-MW Humber project in the U.K., so that’s currently at the FEED process. So under the old recognition methods, the completed contracts method, we would recognize a small amount of revenue as we go through that FEED study, and then effectively you would see nothing else for two to three financial periods until we get towards the end of that contract and revenue would be recognized in one lump sum. If we transfer that to the new version of percentage completion, using ALPHA or POSEIDON, we’d get exactly the same revenue for the FEED study, which would be recognized at the same point in time. But the difference being that at the point that we sign the contract up until delivery, we’d be able to progressively recognize revenue. In that first financial year, you would see revenue happening for that project, and in the second, and then at delivery, until you get to the same point in time. It will allow us to be able to see progress through the factory in the P&L. Dennis Schulz, CEO, ITM Power plc: I think that’s a massive change, if I may add. In the past, when we signed a large contract, 100 MW, more than 100 MW, for example, you would not see relevant revenue from that contract for minimum 2-3 years, right? Then everything would come at once. Under the new PoC, percentage of completion, method, from contract signature, you will see revenue coming in. That is important because it changes the financial profile of the company quite significantly. What it means is, if we sign a new large contract, during a year, now, for the first time, you will see an immediate impact on guidance for the year, and you will see an immediate impact on the financial numbers of th

data.author: Dmac1966
data.content: As of 2026, RES has one of the largest onshore wind pipelines in the UK, with a heavy concentration in Scotland to support the Scottish Government’s target of 20GW by 2030. Their strategy is increasingly to co-locate or pipe this energy directly to industrial green hydrogen hubs through the HYRO joint venture. 1. Onshore Wind Farms in Planning (Scotland focus) RES is currently moving several large-scale projects through the planning system. Because of the size of these turbines, most are now handled directly by the Scottish Government's Energy Consents Unit (ECU) rather than local councils. 2. Where Green Hydrogen Facilities May Be Sited Through the HYRO partnership with Octopus, RES is targeting industrial clusters where they can replace gas usage directly. While their first major wins were in England and Wales, their Scottish strategy focuses on three key areas: • The Grangemouth Cluster: As Scotland’s largest industrial area, this is a primary target. RES/HYRO are looking at sites that can feed the refinery and petrochemical plants, competing with RWE’s nearby hydrogen proposals. • The Whiskey Industry (Speyside/Highlands): RES has a massive presence in Moray and the Highlands (e.g., Hill of Towie, Aberarder). They are exploring "decentralized" hydrogen facilities near these wind farms to supply green heat to nearby distilleries that are off the main gas grid. • Ayrshire Industrial Hub: Building on their wind assets in East Ayrshire (like Sclenteuch), they are eyeing industrial sites in this region to create a local hydrogen economy for heavy transport and manufacturing. 3. Investment Indicators In 2026, the "look" of their investment will shift from pure electricity generation to "integrated energy hubs." • The £3 Billion Fund: You will likely see HYRO announce "Behind the Meter" projects, where a wind farm connects directly to an electrolyser on an industrial site, bypassing some grid charges to make the hydrogen cheaper. • Allocation Round 7 (AR7): Keep an eye on the UK Government’s AR7 results later this year. RES/HYRO typically use these rounds to secure the guaranteed price (CfD) needed to finalize their £3bn investment decisions.

But if they are gambling that say 'plug' is going to go up more than ITM in the same industry, you short one and go long in the other. data.author: Pokerchips
data.content: IFKA as I suggest it is a theory.... they are hedging their short with if you like a long ..I cant say I think they are pure short and not holding any shares ..at the end of the day they must have a net position of either profit or loss....but just as you sit on a loss and wait for a change ..so can they...  is their short bet a hedge within the energy sector against longs elsewhere... these things are usually bigger than the initial focus .. The question must also be ..who is lending them the shares? yes..it is all interesting and open to question...  hydrogen is making progress but is still a way away from proving its place For transparency I like the CEO here and see 2026-27 as the turning point after the loss making contracts finally get finished and the balance sheet moves on from that...but there is still risk for the sector and it will take time yet for new projects to reach revenue on the books

data.author: IKFA
data.content: Pokerchips, sorry I don't understand where that argument goes? Surely any gain they have from the shares they are holding, is cancelled out 1:1  with any loss on the shares which they have borrowed? It is like a zero sum game with a rent attached. For ease of numbers lets say they bought 24 million shares when the price was 26p ( so they hold the same number of shares which they have borrowed), they are enjoying the price rise up to 68p, but all of the shares which they have to buy back to cover the short has lost them exactly the same on the way up, then they have to cover the rent / interest on the borrowing ??? I understand that this would have locked in their profit at 26p but why keep the short open when you now have the ability to close it with shares which you have bought?  This is now "dead holdings" for them, which surely a hedge fund want their investment working,  not invested into a vehicle which cannot make any profit as it remains the same whichever way the stock moves ?? Also are there not rules in place to stop this practice, they have to declare "net position" to the FSA? If they have been "trading" on the way up and taking profits I could see the argument but just buying and holding makes no sense at all to me. Am I missing something?

data.author: Pokerchips
data.content: " why would they still be paying rent on 24 million shares? " well...my thoery would run along the lines  that maybe it is because they are in fact holding some shares and from them profiting from the share price gain and as such covering the "rent" cost of borrowing shares.. 2.91% short is what they have borrowed ... doesnt mean they are not actually holding any and it doesnt in itself mean they have actually sold everything they have borrowed.. I borrow shares from an owner will to offering them for borrowing... , I pay the fee..what I do with them is up to me from that point on.. Should anything turn in the hydrogen market in terms of take up and demand then the likes of Helikon will be ready to sell the shares they hold..... in the meantime those shares they hold are gaining in value and offset the ones they have sold...
